### 5. Handling Missing Values (NAs)

#Check for missing values (returns TRUE/FALSE)
is.na(df)
is.na(df["VarA"])

#Filter out missing values
b <- a[!is.na(a)]

#Replace missing values with a specific number (e.g., 0)
a[is.na(a)] <- 0

#Calculate math while ignoring NAs
mean(a, na.rm = TRUE)

#Replace missing values with the Mean
df$VarB[is.na(df$VarB)] <- mean(df$VarB, na.rm=TRUE)

#Replace missing values with the Median
df$VarC[is.na(df$VarC)] <- median(df$VarC, na.rm=TRUE)

#Replace missing values with the Standard Deviation (SD)
df$VarA[is.na(df$VarA)] <- sd(na.omit(df$VarA))

### 7. Data Types and Factor Manipulation

#Check the data type of a column
class(iris$Species)

#View values of categories/levels for a factor variable
levels(iris$Species)

#Convert a categorical (factor) column to numeric
iris$Species_numeric <- as.numeric(iris$Species)


### 8. Statistics and Data Transformation (Standardization)

#Calculate the Mean
mean_value <- mean(iris$Sepal.Length)

#Calculate the Standard Deviation
sd_value <- sd(iris$Sepal.Length)

#Standardize a column manually (Z-score calculation)
iris$Sepal.Length_z_manual <- (iris$Sepal.Length - mean_value) / sd_value

#Standardize a column using R's built-in function
iris$Sepal.Length_z <- scale(iris$Sepal.Length)
